commit_message:
Optimise dhcp spawning performance

DRAFT! doesn't work yet!

Closes-Bug: 1279334

Change-Id: Ic6aa55ba5b4df99fc033b78d9b96a98812c14cd3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/82/81482/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
dhcp_hostsfile = '' addn_hosts = '' options = None self._generate_files() is_first, # Boolean to know if we are yielding the first host. is_last, # Boolean to know if we are yielding the last host. is_last = False counter = 0 is_first = counter is 0 # Store result to be a loop in advance because we want to know # if we are on the last iteration before StopItertion being # raised if is_first: # yield nothing yet pass else: # yield previous iteration's result yield result # Store result for next yield. result = ( port, alloc, hostname, fqdn, is_first, is_last ) counter += 1 # We yield only if we have 1 result or more if counter: is_last = True yield (port, alloc, hostname, fqdn, is_first, is_last) def _generate_files(self): """Build --dhcp-hostsfile --addn-hosts and --dhcp-optsfile files. Write the content of the -dhcp-hostsfile --addn-hosts and --dhcp-optsfile files, and return their names. We first create the file contents, and then write the contents into a file as a separate operation for atomicity and to avoid competing writes. """ # Create the File Objects dhcp_hostsfile = six.StringIO() addn_hosts = six.StringIO() options = [] # Fill the File Objects for (port, alloc, hostname, fqdn, fi, li) in self._iter_hosts(): self._add_to_dhcp_hostsfile(dhcp_hostsfile, port, alloc, fqdn) self._add_to_addn_hosts(addn_hosts, alloc, hostname, fqdn) self._build_options(fi, li, options, port) # Write the files to Disk. self.dhcp_hostsfile = dhcp_hostsfile.getvalue() self._output_hosts_file(write_to_disk=True) self.addn_hosts = addn_hosts.getvalue() self._output_addn_hosts_file(write_to_disk=True) self.options = options self._output_opts_file(write_to_disk=True) def _add_to_dhcp_hostsfile(self, dhcp_hostsfile, port, alloc, fqdn): """Writes into a dnsmasq compatible dhcp hosts file object. The generated file can be sent to the --dhcp-hostsfile option of dnsmasq,which lists the hosts on the network which should receive a dhcp lease. :dhcp_hostsfile: a File Object :port: a DictModel instance representing a port :alloc: NetModel instance representing a port allocation. :fqdn: the Fully Qualified Domain Name as a string. """ set_tag = '' # (dzyu) Check if it is legal ipv6 address, if so, need wrap # it with '[]' to let dnsmasq to distinguish MAC address from # IPv6 address. ip_address = alloc.ip_address if netaddr.valid_ipv6(ip_address): ip_address = '[%s]' % ip_address if getattr(port, 'extra_dhcp_opts', False): if self.version >= self.MINIMUM_VERSION: set_tag = 'set:' dhcp_hostsfile.write('%s,%s,%s,%s%s
' % (port.mac_address, fqdn, ip_address, set_tag, port.id)) else: dhcp_hostsfile.write('%s,%s,%s
' % (port.mac_address, fqdn, ip_address)) def _output_hosts_file(self, write_to_disk=False): """Return the name of the dnsmasq compatible dhcp hosts file. Writes the the contents to the file if `write_to_disk` is True """ if write_to_disk: utils.replace_file(name, self.dhcp_hostsfile) filename = self._output_hosts_file() def _add_to_addn_hosts(self, addn_hosts, alloc, hostname, fqdn): """Writes in a dnsmasq compatible additional hosts file. `_fill_hosts_file` method). # It is compulsory to write the `fqdn` before the `hostname` in # order to obtain it in PTR responses. addn_hosts.write('%s	%s %s
' % (alloc.ip_address, fqdn, hostname)) def _output_addn_hosts_file(self, write_to_disk=False): """Writes the dnsmasq compatible additional hosts file.""" name = self.get_conf_file_name('addn_hosts') if write_to_disk: utils.replace_file(name, self.addn_hosts) return name def __get_subnet_idx_map(self, options): """Return a subnet_idx_map and update options accordingly. :options: a list used to construct a dnsmasq compatible options file. :return: a subnet_idx_map dict. """ return subnet_idx_map def _build_options(self, initialize, finalize, options, port): """Build the necessary options for a dnsmasq compatible options file. This method is to be called several time on a loop so we need: :initialize: a boolean indicating if we have to perform some initialization on the options list. :finalize: a boolean indicating if we have to perform some finalization on the options list. :options: a list used to construct a dnsmasq compatible options file. :port: a DictModel instance representing a network port """ if initialize: # We will need those for the next iterations. self.__subnet_idx_map = self.__get_subnet_idx_map(options) self.__dhcp_ips = collections.defaultdict(list) if getattr(port, 'extra_dhcp_opts', False): options.extend( self._format_option(port.id, opt.opt_name, opt.opt_value) for opt in port.extra_dhcp_opts) # provides all dnsmasq ip as dns-server if there is more than # one dnsmasq for a subnet and there is no dns-server submitted # by the server if port.device_owner == 'network:dhcp': for ip in port.fixed_ips: i = self.__subnet_idx_map.get(ip.subnet_id) if i is None: continue self.__dhcp_ips[i].append(ip.ip_address) if finalize: for i, ips in self.__dhcp_ips.items(): if len(ips) > 1: options.append(self._format_option(i, 'dns-server', ','.join(ips))) # Make some cleanup del self.__subnet_idx_map, self.__dhcp_ips def _output_opts_file(self, write_to_disk=False): """Write a dnsmasq compatible options file.""" if write_to_disk: utils.replace_file(name, '
'.join(self.options))
deleted_lines:
yield (port, alloc, hostname, fqdn) def _output_hosts_file(self): """Writes a dnsmasq compatible dhcp hosts file. The generated file is sent to the --dhcp-hostsfile option of dnsmasq, and lists the hosts on the network which should receive a dhcp lease. """ buf = six.StringIO() for (port, alloc, hostname, name) in self._iter_hosts(): set_tag = '' # (dzyu) Check if it is legal ipv6 address, if so, need wrap # it with '[]' to let dnsmasq to distinguish MAC address from # IPv6 address. ip_address = alloc.ip_address if netaddr.valid_ipv6(ip_address): ip_address = '[%s]' % ip_address if getattr(port, 'extra_dhcp_opts', False): if self.version >= self.MINIMUM_VERSION: set_tag = 'set:' buf.write('%s,%s,%s,%s%s
' % (port.mac_address, name, ip_address, set_tag, port.id)) else: buf.write('%s,%s,%s
' % (port.mac_address, name, ip_address)) utils.replace_file(name, buf.getvalue()) filename = self.get_conf_file_name('host') def _output_addn_hosts_file(self): """Writes a dnsmasq compatible additional hosts file. `_output_hosts_file` method). buf = six.StringIO() for (port, alloc, hostname, fqdn) in self._iter_hosts(): # It is compulsory to write the `fqdn` before the `hostname` in # order to obtain it in PTR responses. buf.write('%s	%s %s
' % (alloc.ip_address, fqdn, hostname)) addn_hosts = self.get_conf_file_name('addn_hosts') utils.replace_file(addn_hosts, buf.getvalue()) return addn_hosts def _output_opts_file(self): """Write a dnsmasq compatible options file.""" options = [] dhcp_ips = collections.defaultdict(list) for port in self.network.ports: if getattr(port, 'extra_dhcp_opts', False): options.extend( self._format_option(port.id, opt.opt_name, opt.opt_value) for opt in port.extra_dhcp_opts) # provides all dnsmasq ip as dns-server if there is more than # one dnsmasq for a subnet and there is no dns-server submitted # by the server if port.device_owner == constants.DEVICE_OWNER_DHCP: for ip in port.fixed_ips: i = subnet_idx_map.get(ip.subnet_id) if i is None: continue dhcp_ips[i].append(ip.ip_address) for i, ips in dhcp_ips.items(): if len(ips) > 1: options.append(self._format_option(i, 'dns-server', ','.join(ips))) utils.replace_file(name, '
'.join(options))

commit_message:
Add SR-IOV ML2 driver support for VLAN trunking.

Add VLAN trunking support for SR-IOV VFs based on Intel i40e NIC
driver.

The current SRIOV driver for trunking is based on Intel i40e NIC
driver with following requirements:-

hardware: Intel Ethernet Network Adapter XXV710 (25GbE)
Driver: Intel i40e v2.7.12 onwards

Closes-Bug: 1794771

Change-Id: I9f679e109290c3f6955dd63227d802355ee71d2d
Co-Authored-By: Manjeet Singh Bhatia <manjeet.s.bhatia@intel.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/67/665467/58 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from neutron_lib.callbacks import events as local_events from neutron_lib.callbacks import registry from neutron_lib.callbacks import resources as local_resources from neutron_lib.services.trunk import constants as t_const from oslo_log import log as logging import oslo_messaging from neutron.api.rpc.callbacks import events from neutron.api.rpc.handlers import resources_rpc from neutron.services.trunk.drivers.linuxbridge.agent import lb_trunk_driver from neutron.services.trunk.drivers.mech_sriov import utils as sriov_utils from neutron.services.trunk.drivers.mech_sriov.agent import trunk_plumber from neutron.services.trunk.rpc import agent as trunk_rpc LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def init_handler(resource, event, trigger, payload=None): """Handler for agent init event.""" # Set up agent-side RPC for receiving trunk events; SriovTrunkDriver(sriov_utils) @registry.has_registry_receivers class SriovTrunkDriver(trunk_rpc.TrunkSkeleton): """Driver responsible for handling trunk/subport/port events. Receives data model events from the server and VIF events from the agent and uses these to drive a Plumber instance to trigger backend SRIOV commands for trunks. """ def __init__(self, plumber=None, sriov_utils=None, trunk_api=None): super(SriovTrunkDriver, self).__init__() self.sriov_utils = sriov_utils or sriov_utils.SriovNicUtils() self._plumber = plumber or trunk_plumber.Plumber() self._tapi = trunk_api or _TrunkAPI(trunk_rpc.TrunkStub()) super(SriovTrunkDriver, self).__init__() def handle_trunks(self, context, resource_type, trunks, event_type): """Trunk data model change from the server.""" for trunk in trunks: if event_type in (events.UPDATED, events.CREATED): self._tapi.put_trunk(trunk.port_id, trunk) self.wire_trunk(context, trunk) elif event_type == events.DELETED: self.unwire_trunk(trunk) self._tapi.put_trunk(trunk.port_id, None) def handle_subports(self, context, resource_type, subports, event_type): """Subport data model change from the server.""" affected_trunks = set() if event_type == events.DELETED: method = self.delete_trunk_subport else: method = self._tapi.put_trunk_subport for s in subports: affected_trunks.add(s['trunk_id']) method(s['trunk_id'], s) for trunk_id in affected_trunks: trunk = self._tapi.get_trunk_by_id(context, trunk_id) if not trunk: continue self.wire_trunk(context, trunk) @registry.receives(local_resources.PORT_DEVICE, [local_events.AFTER_DELETE]) def agent_port_delete(self, resource, event, trigger, payload=None): """Agent informed us a VIF was removed.""" # NOTE(deepaktiwari): We don't update the trunk status to DOWN as we # don't want to race with another agent that the trunk may have been # moved to. port_id = payload.latest_state['port_id'] trunk = self._tapi.get_trunk(payload.context, port_id) if trunk: self.unwire_trunk(trunk) self._tapi.put_trunk(port_id, None) return port_params = self.get_sriov_port_params(port_id) self._plumber.apply_vlan_filter(port_params, None) self._tapi.put_trunk(port_id, None) @registry.receives(local_resources.PORT_DEVICE, [local_events.AFTER_UPDATE]) def agent_port_change(self, resource, event, trigger, payload=None): """The agent hath informed us thusly of a port update or create.""" port_id = payload.latest_state['port_id'] trunk = self._tapi.get_trunk(payload.context, port_id) if trunk: # a wild trunk has appeared! make its children self.wire_trunk(payload.context, trunk) return # clear any VLANs in case this was a trunk that changed status while # agent was offline. tp_params = self.get_sriov_port_params(port_id) self._plumber.apply_vlan_filter(tp_params, None) self._tapi.put_trunk(port_id, None) def wire_trunk(self, context, trunk): """Wire up subports while keeping the server trunk status apprised.""" if not self.trunk_on_host(trunk): LOG.debug("Trunk %s not present on this host", trunk.port_id) return self._tapi.bind_subports_to_host(context, trunk) try: for s in trunk.subports: sp_params = self.get_sriov_port_params(s.port_id) self._plumber.apply_vlan_filter(tp_params, s.segmentation_id) vlans_ranges_str = vlans_ranges_str + "," + s.segmentation_id tp_params = self.get_sriov_port_params(trunk.port_id) self._plumber.apply_vlan_filter(tp_params, vlans_ranges_str) self._tapi.set_trunk_status( context, trunk, t_const.TRUNK_ACTIVE_STATUS) except Exception: # something broke LOG.exception("Failure setting up subports for %s", trunk.port_id) self._tapi.set_trunk_status(context, trunk, t_const.TRUNK_DEGRADED_STATUS) def unwire_trunk(self, context, trunk): """Unwire subports while keeping the server trunk status apprised.""" try: tp_params = self.get_sriov_port_params(trunk.port_id) self._plumber.apply_vlan_filter(tp_params, None) for s in trunk.subports: delete_trunk_subport(context, trunk.trunk_id, s) self._tapi.set_trunk_status(context, trunk, t_const.TRUNK_DOWN_STATUS) except Exception: # something broke LOG.exception("Failure unwiring subports for %s", trunk.port_id) self._tapi.set_trunk_status(context, trunk, t_const.TRUNK_DEGRADED_STATUS) def delete_trunk_subport(self, context, trunk_id, subport): """Remove subport from trunk.""" LOG.debug("Deleting subport %(sub)s from trunk %(trunk)s", dict(sub=subport, trunk=trunk_id)) #ToDo sp_params = self.get_sriov_port_params(subport.port_id) self._plumber.apply_vlan_filter(sp_params, None) self._tapi.delete_trunk_subport(trunk_id, subport) def get_sriov_port_params(self, context, port_id): """Fetch Sriov parameters for a given port_id.""" port = self.fetch_port(context, port_id) if port: return self.sriov_utils.get_sriov_port_params(port) else return None def trunk_on_host(self, trunk): """Returns true if trunk port VF is present on the host.""" #ToDo tp = self.fetch_port(context, trunk.port_id) if tp and tp['binding:host_id'] == host: return True return False class _TrunkAPI(lb_trunk_driver._TrunkAPI): """Our secret stash of trunks stored by port ID. Tell no one.""" def fetch_port(self, context, port_id): try: port = self.server_api.get_port_details(context, port_id) LOG.debug("Found port %(port)s for port-id %(p)s", dict(p=port_id, port=port)) return port except resources_rpc.ResourceNotFound: return None except oslo_messaging.RemoteError as e: if e.exc_type != 'CallbackNotFound': raise LOG.debug("Port %s details can not be fetched.", port_id) return None def __init__(self, trunk_stub): self.server_api = trunk_stub self._trunk_by_port_id = {} self._trunk_by_id = {} self._sub_port_id_to_trunk_port_id = {} def _fetch_trunk(self, context, port_id): try: t = self.server_api.get_trunk_details(context, port_id) LOG.debug("Found trunk %(t)s for port %(p)s", dict(p=port_id, t=t)) return t except resources_rpc.ResourceNotFound: return None except oslo_messaging.RemoteError as e: if e.exc_type != 'CallbackNotFound': raise LOG.debug("Trunk plugin disabled on server. Assuming port %s is " "not a trunk.", port_id) return None def set_trunk_status(self, context, trunk, status): self.server_api.update_trunk_status(context, trunk.id, status) def bind_subports_to_host(self, context, trunk): self.server_api.update_subport_bindings(context, trunk.sub_ports) def put_trunk_subport(self, trunk_id, subport): LOG.debug("Adding subport %(sub)s to trunk %(trunk)s", dict(sub=subport, trunk=trunk_id)) if trunk_id not in self._trunk_by_id: # not on this agent return trunk = self._trunk_by_id[trunk_id] trunk.sub_ports = [s for s in trunk.sub_ports if s.port_id != subport.port_id] + [subport] def delete_trunk_subport(self, trunk_id, subport): LOG.debug("Removing subport %(sub)s from trunk %(trunk)s", dict(sub=subport, trunk=trunk_id)) if trunk_id not in self._trunk_by_id: # not on this agent return trunk = self._trunk_by_id[trunk_id] trunk.sub_ports = [s for s in trunk.sub_ports if s.port_id != subport.port_id] def put_trunk(self, port_id, trunk): if port_id in self._trunk_by_port_id: # already existed. expunge sub_port cross ref self._sub_port_id_to_trunk_port_id = { s: p for s, p in self._sub_port_id_to_trunk_port_id.items() if p != port_id} self._trunk_by_port_id[port_id] = trunk if not trunk: return self._trunk_by_id[trunk.id] = trunk for sub in trunk.sub_ports: self._sub_port_id_to_trunk_port_id[sub.port_id] = trunk.port_id def get_trunk_by_id(self, context, trunk_id): """Gets trunk object based on trunk_id. None if not in cache.""" return self._trunk_by_id.get(trunk_id) def get_trunk(self, context, port_id): """Gets trunk object for port_id. None if not trunk.""" if port_id not in self._trunk_by_port_id: # TODO(kevinbenton): ask the server for *all* trunk port IDs on # start and eliminate asking the server if every port is a trunk # TODO(kevinbenton): clear this on AMQP reconnect LOG.debug("Cache miss for port %s, fetching from server", port_id) self.put_trunk(port_id, self._fetch_trunk(context, port_id)) return self.get_trunk(context, port_id) return self._trunk_by_port_id[port_id] def get_trunk_for_subport(self, context, port_id): """Returns trunk if port_id is a subport, else None.""" trunk_port = self._sub_port_id_to_trunk_port_id.get(port_id) if trunk_port: return self.get_trunk(context, trunk_port)

The imp module is deprecated[1] since version 3.4, use importlib to
instead

global to an object. Meaning that if you mark an object for new_facade =
True, *all* business logic using the object must also switch to new

impossible to do without changing thousands loosely related lines of

commit_message:
objects: automatically detect whether engine facade is used

While we added new_facade object attribute to framework and it has its
niche and used in some stadium subprojects, it's not ideal because it's
global to an object. Meaning that if you mark an object for new_facade =
True, *all* business logic using the object must also switch to new
facade in the same step, which is a pain and sometimes close to
impossible to do without changing thousands loosely related lines of
code in multiple modules. It would be nice to instead use objects as
usual in different contexts - some using engine facade and some still
using session.begin(...) - and allow the OVO framework to pick the right
way to nest subtransactions.

This patch does exactly that. We call an internal function from oslo.db
and check whether it raises an exception. If it does, it means that the
engine facade is not used; otherwise, we use the new style of nested
transactions management.

By default, if session is not active when OVO action is called, we stick
to the old facade. Once we are done with switching the rest of the
plugin code / OVO objects to the new facade, we will rip off the
transitionary logic.

Change-Id: Ia05df925eccf3c9d397748f282e995203a058de9
Partially-Implements: blueprint enginefacade-switch
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db
(cherry picked from commit 92b95815318806f90eca987145ad453782dd7041)

added_lines: from neutron.db import api as db_api # with no engine facade, we didn't have distinction between r/o and # r/w transactions and so we always call commit even for getters when # no facade is used if self._test_class._use_db_facade else SQLALCHEMY_COMMIT) with db_api.autonested_transaction(self.context.session): self._test_class.get_objects(self.context) self.assertEqual(1, mock_exit.call_count) def test_get_objects_single_transaction_enginefacade(self): with mock.patch(self._get_ro_txn_exit_func_name()) as mock_exit: with db_api.context_manager.reader.using(self.context): self._test_class.get_objects(self.context) with db_api.autonested_transaction(self.context.session): obj = self._test_class.get_object(self.context, **obj._get_composite_keys()) self.assertEqual(1, mock_exit.call_count) def test_get_object_single_transaction_enginefacade(self): obj = self._make_object(self.obj_fields[0]) obj.create() with mock.patch(self._get_ro_txn_exit_func_name()) as mock_exit: with db_api.context_manager.reader.using(self.context): obj = self._test_class.get_object(self.context, **obj._get_composite_keys())
deleted_lines: # for old engine facade, we didn't have distinction between r/o and r/w # transactions and so we always call commit even for getters when the # old facade is used if self._test_class.new_facade else SQLALCHEMY_COMMIT) self._test_class.get_objects(self.context) obj = self._test_class.get_object(self.context, **obj._get_composite_keys())

commit_message:
Switch from unittest2 compat methods to Python 3.x methods

With the removal of Python 2.x we can remove the unittest2 compat
wrappers and switch to assertCountEqual instead of assertItemsEqual

We have been able to use them since then, because
testtools required unittest2, which still included it. With testtools
removing Python 2.7 support [3][4], we will lose support for
assertItemsEqual, so we should switch to use assertCountEqual.

[1] - https://bugs.python.org/issue17866
[2] - https://hg.python.org/cpython/rev/d9921cb6e3cd
[3] - testing-cabal/testtools#286
[4] - testing-cabal/testtools#277

Change-Id: I2fa17822ffaa5c87397ad6840c962e9308c95d6a

By default, when creating logical routers in ovn, ovn-northd creates

a number of logical routers connected to the same network though,
with 800 routers resulting in over 640k entries in lr_in_ip_input table.

'}]
commit_message:
[OVN] disable neighour learning from ARP requests for routers

By default, when creating logical routers in ovn, ovn-northd creates
logical flows to handle arp-related traffic. This scales poorly with
a number of logical routers connected to the same network though,
with 800 routers resulting in over 640k entries in lr_in_ip_input table.

This patch sets two options on each created routers to limit a number
of logical flows created in that table.

Closes-Bug: #1897095
Change-Id: I9572f91281a719230749fd1222ae96e9e06b4dc6

commit_message:
Support SR-IOV in OVN migration infrared plugin

This patch adds SR-IOV support to OVN migration plugin.
This includes necessary changes in overcloud deploy templates
and ability to create SR-IOV resources.

Change-Id: I5074601605c67be6aada232e42ba94de6c60e56e
Closes-bug: #1899009

added_lines: sriov: type: Bool help: If the environment uses SR-IOV default: False resources_type: type: Value help: | Type of resources we want to create normal: creates amount of VMs matching number of compute nodes dvr: same as normal but creates DVR router instead of HA sriov_no_pf: as normal but creates also VMs with SR-IOV VF(direct) ports sriov_full: as sriov_no_pf but creates also VMs with SR-IOV PF(direct-physical) ports choices: - normal - dvr - sriov_no_pf - sriov_full default: normal default: cirros-0.4.0-x86_64-disk.img

commit_message:
Fix bug for updating external_port of floating IP port forwarding rule

When an existed port forwarding rule is updating on the floating IP,
if the external_port field which contained in the updated content is the same
as that in other port forwarding rule entries under the floating IP, Neutron
should grab the problem and return 400.

Change-Id: I4f9e73c157807049a713f6cc5ba784bc671247b2
Closes-Bug: #1896563

commit_message:
[OVN] Gate on the released version of OVN for the multinode job

This patch is adding a OVN multinode job with a released version of OVS
in the queue and moving the one based on the master branch of OVS/OVN to
the experimental gate (since those are unstable by nature).

Change-Id: I5e16bab288d47d5ce01ddcc644b5e92e50bedd72
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Fix bug for updating floating IP port forwarding rule IP and port mismatch update success.

When we update forwarding rules of floating IP,
if updated floating IP port forwarding rule internal_ Ip_ Address and internal_ port_ ID mismatch,
we can update success, that is a problem

Change-Id: I38dd0d0640ae7a8469291fbac2139bab45cdd5c2
Closes-Bug: #1896571

Add new healthcheck plugin NeutronAgentsHealthcheck

Add new oslo_middleware healthcheck plugin NeutronAgentsHealthcheck.

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from collections import defaultdict from oslo_db import exception as db_exc from oslo_log import log as logging from oslo_middleware.healthcheck import pluginbase from neutron_lib import context from neutron.objects import agent as agent_obj LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class NeutronAgentsHealthcheck(pluginbase.HealthcheckBaseExtension): """Neutron Agents healthcheck oslo_middleware plugin. This plugin checks neutron agents, and if all agent's admin_state is True return Ok, otherwise returns the number of failing agents and the failing agents on each host. """ def healthcheck(self, server_port): LOG.debug('AAAAA server_port=%s', server_port) ctx = context.get_admin_context() try: agents = agent_obj.Agent.get_objects(ctx) except db_exc.DBError: LOG.warning('Cannot fetch agents info!') return pluginbase.HealthcheckResult( available=False, reason='Cannot fetch agents information from DB!') agents_state = [agent.admin_state_up for agent in agents] if all(agents_state): results = defaultdict(int) for agent in agents: results[agent.host] += 1 return pluginbase.HealthcheckResult( available=True, reason="All neutron agents are up, " "total: %s" % len(agents_state), details=results) else: down_agents = [agent.admin_state_up for agent in agents if not agent.admin_state_up] results = defaultdict(list) for agent in agents: if not agent.admin_state_up: results[agent.host].append( {agent.binary: agent.admin_state_up}) return pluginbase.HealthcheckResult( available=False, reason="Not all neutron agents are up, " "%s in DOWN state from %s" % (len(down_agents), len(agents_state)), details=results )

commit_message:
Set process name for agents

Now that we use setproctitle for neutron-server workers (and
neutron-keepalived-state-change), this has the side effect of changing
the process name for agents, impacting some monitoring systems. More
details in launchpad bug.

This patch fixes it by setting the name with setproctitle to:
agent name (original process name).

Also use the newly introduced name constants to replace existing
hardcoded uses.

Change-Id: I74c3a4d3e9f833752571a75f196560cd45529385
Closes-Bug: #1881297
(cherry picked from commit 5ce0595803e72157a82f086b520f454786100872)

commit_message:
WIP: Add IPv6-only tunnel jobs

Add ML2/OVS and OVN jobs that set TUNNEL_IP_VERSION=6
to verify they can run over IPv6 tunnel endpoints.

NOTE: If these work, it might be best to just roll this
config into the base tempest IPv6-only jobs?  Or just
set by default in the neutron jobs?

Change-Id: I30fe98526bc9c56b30637bd983c9e6ff0fdf5bc9
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/710519/

commit_message:
Drop old port when the ovs_use_veth changes.

The ovs_use_veth parameter does not take effet for existing ovs
interfaces. For example, the qr-dev interface already exists in
the qrouter namespace, when change the ovs_use_veth from false
to true, the veth interface can't be created. So need to add the
_drop_old_port() to drop old port when the ovs_use_veth changes.

Change-Id: I3eeae671e6ab1b24aadfa20b10d13556bdb1b1ac
Closes-Bug: #1894799
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/91/750291/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _drop_old_port(self, port_id, bridge, device_name, namespace): if not bridge: bridge = self.conf.ovs_integration_bridge ovs = ovs_lib.OVSBridge(bridge) ovs_port = ovs.get_vif_port_by_id(port_id) if not ovs_port: return port_name = ovs_port.port_name if port_name.startswith(constants.TAP_DEVICE_PREFIX): pre_ovs_use_veth = True else: pre_ovs_use_veth = False if pre_ovs_use_veth != self.conf.ovs_use_veth: # Drop old port when the ovs_use_veth changes. if pre_ovs_use_veth: # Drop old veth port when ovs_use_veth change from # true to false. ovs.delete_port(port_name) device = ip_lib.IPDevice(device_name, namespace=namespace) device.link.delete() else: # Drop old port when ovs_use_veth change from false # to true. ovs.delete_port(device_name) self._drop_old_port(port_id, bridge, device_name, namespace)

commit_message:
Remove references to "tenant_id" from api.v2.base.Controller

The migration from "tenant_id" to "project_id" finised in Ocata,
but "tenant_id" is still present in many places in the code. This
patch removes this reference from the API Controller class.

Change-Id: I3b4ddc9c05281930c96bdc970de84cce9f857b79
Closes-Bug: #1858783

added_lines: # TODO(ralonsoh): some attributes still have 'tenant_id'. This # parameter should be removed. if attr_name == 'tenant_id': if 'project_id' not in item[self._resource]: # no 'project_id' - no quota check project_id = item[self._resource]['project_id'] request_deltas[project_id] += 1 network_owner = network['project_id'] if network_owner != resource_item['project_id']:
deleted_lines: If the attribute map contains a tenant_id policy, then include project_id to bring the resource into the brave new world. if 'tenant_id' in policy_attrs: policy_attrs.add('project_id') # TODO(amotoki): At now, all attribute maps have tenant_id and # determine excluded attributes based on tenant_id. # We need to migrate tenant_id to project_id later # as attr_info is referred to in various places and we need # to check all logis carefully. if attr_name == 'project_id': # TODO(amotoki): As mentioned in the above TODO, # we treat project_id and tenant_id equivalently. # This should be migrated to project_id in Ocata. if attr_name == 'tenant_id': attributes_to_exclude.append('project_id') if 'tenant_id' not in item[self._resource]: # no tenant_id - no quota check tenant_id = item[self._resource]['tenant_id'] request_deltas[tenant_id] += 1 network_owner = network['tenant_id'] if network_owner != resource_item['tenant_id']:

commit_message:
[WIP] Allow multiple segments to same host on routed networks

Allows multiple segments of a routed network to be bound to the same
host. This allows deployers to create multiple segments on a routed
network, attach multiple segments to the same host and correctly
be able to deploy VMs from it.

Changes:
Patches 1-6: Core changes
Patch 7: Add Alembic migration to backfill segment_id bridge_name
Patch 8: Fixes for alembic migration. Fix plugin comment.
Patch 9: Rebase
Patch 10: Rebase + fix bug in get_vif_details to always set bridge_name
Patch 11: Rebase

Change-Id: Ibcc90e9d25f863e8577e4092fef786c25755f35a
Closes-Bug: 1764738
Co-Authored-By: Kris Lindgren <klindgren@godaddy.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/15/623115/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # TODO(wwriverrat) Is there better way to do this? # If a port has an IP that came from a segment, then attempt # to bind using that segment_id rather than all of the possible # segments for the network. # The reason for this: A host with multiple segments associated # to it can use a bindable segment before the correct segment # is found. # See neutron.plugins.ml2.plugin.Ml2Plugin._bind_port if 'fixed_ips' in context.current: ips = context.current['fixed_ips'] for ip in ips: if 'segment_id' in ip: for segment in context.segments_to_bind: if ip['segment_id'] == segment['id']: if self.try_to_bind_segment_for_agent( context, segment, agent): LOG.debug("Bound using segment: %s", segment) return vif_details = self.vif_details # TODO(klindgren): fix this so where this is returned correctly from # linux_bridge_agent on port binding if segment: bridge_name = 'brq' + segment['id'][:11] vif_details[portbindings.VIF_DETAILS_BRIDGE_NAME] = bridge_name return vif_details

commit_message:
neutron-keepalived-state-change file descriptor leak

the commit 21935365f2 fix the neutron-keepalived-state-change script by replace
the eventlet to threading, now the script use threading + eventlet.green.subprocess
to send garp, this works, but each time the send_garp function called, there
is a file left in /proc/<pid of neutron-keepalived-state-change>/fd, this cause
the file descriptor leak, and then cause the script to consume huge memory until
kernel OOM.

Closes-Bug: #1907411
Change-Id: I74ec64bcaae3ec104b4833d36d547ac7e1b9c159

commit_message:
Enable querier for multicast (IGMP) in OVN

This patch is adding IGMP querier support in the OVN driver.
IGMP querier is working only when IGMP snooping is enable.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/762818
Change-Id: I0b9e1c0b7cf467c6c507102cd1fae72b68be90cc

commit_message:
Add tenant_id check when listing security groups

When listing security groups, even if the 'tenant_id' does not exist,
the default security group for the tenant will be generated. This patch
calls keystone to verify whether the 'tenant_id' exists.

Closes-Bug: #1912747
Change-Id: Iffc08096ccfee5a2e6899ad652d4cc27cc8c885b

commit_message:
Fix update port sgs without specifing "device_owner" attr bug

When update a port of which device_owner startswith 'network:'
with security_groups attribute, the port can be successfully
updated. On the contrarythose network device owner ports
should not be added security_groups.

Change-Id: I4203834d502298e325eedefc71a2d77e8f41ea50
Closes-Bug: #1859765

commit_message:
Limit number of the test workers used in functional tests job

To limit resource usage and to avoid killing MySQL server by
the oom-killer, let's limit number of test workers from 8 to 4
in the functional tests CI job.

Change-Id: Ic4b1dad3184fe2e2c541a3f3442f0b78dab87db6

subject: Improve "get_devices_with_ip" performance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-03-10 08:00:33.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/functional/agent/linux/test_ip_lib.py', 'neutron/agent/linux/ip_lib.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/test_ip_lib.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b0bc31e63f957fc23762d9eb0c663c627e3b7c1f', 'message': 'Improve "get_devices_with_ip" performance

As reported in LP#1896734, there is a limit in the size of information
that can be transmitted in one single message between an application
and the privsep daemon. The read socket buffer is limited in size;
a message exceeding this size will generate an exception.

In order to limit the amount of information to be sent, this patch
improves the performance of "get_devices_with_ip". In the previous
implementation, the whole list of network devices from a namespace
was retrieved. In some environments, the list of devices could be
so big that the list returned by "privileged.get_link_devices" can
exceed the read buffer size (as reported in the LP bug when the
OVS agent tries to retrieve the list of IP addresses in the system).

Now the function calls "privileged.get_ip_addresses", that returns
a much smaller list. This patch is also reducing the number of system
calls to just one; the previous implementation was retrieving first
the devices link information list (that method was returning a much
bigger blob) and then, per device, retrieving the IP address
information.

Conflicts:
    neutron/agent/linux/ip_lib.py
    neutron/tests/functional/agent/linux/test_ip_lib.py
    neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/test_ip_lib.py

Change-Id: I97ada62484023b9833ed12afd68eb4c8d337fd1f
Related-Bug: #1896734
(cherry picked from commit a6cdf273c06a3bba713d7b8d0ef3a9b71b0ffc57)
'}]
commit_message:
Improve "get_devices_with_ip" performance

As reported in LP#1896734, there is a limit in the size of information
that can be transmitted in one single message between an application
and the privsep daemon. The read socket buffer is limited in size;
a message exceeding this size will generate an exception.

In order to limit the amount of information to be sent, this patch
improves the performance of "get_devices_with_ip". In the previous
implementation, the whole list of network devices from a namespace
was retrieved. In some environments, the list of devices could be
so big that the list returned by "privileged.get_link_devices" can
exceed the read buffer size (as reported in the LP bug when the
OVS agent tries to retrieve the list of IP addresses in the system).

Now the function calls "privileged.get_ip_addresses", that returns
a much smaller list. This patch is also reducing the number of system
calls to just one; the previous implementation was retrieving first
the devices link information list (that method was returning a much
bigger blob) and then, per device, retrieving the IP address
information.

Conflicts:
    neutron/agent/linux/ip_lib.py
    neutron/tests/functional/agent/linux/test_ip_lib.py
    neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/test_ip_lib.py

Change-Id: I97ada62484023b9833ed12afd68eb4c8d337fd1f
Related-Bug: #1896734
(cherry picked from commit a6cdf273c06a3bba713d7b8d0ef3a9b71b0ffc57)

commit_message:
Fix check_subnet_router filters

Device owner of router ports is not limited to network:router_interface
and can also be network:router_interface_distributed or
network:ha_router_replicated_interface depending on the router
to which port is attached.

Currently, when HA router is used, trove fails with:
`Subnet is not associated with router` since port does not pass filter

Change-Id: Ie8b3884dd13147f29d5632275fa5c75e801e04c8

commit_message:
Fix default admin_or_owner policy expression

By default not even an admin can use the get_summary endpoint with
all_tenants=True or using a tenant_id parameter. This commit fixes that.

This rule is now the same as how cinder defines admin_or_owner.

Change-Id: I3e34927e8ab88f25d2975b4dbac89b52a7d94c98
(cherry picked from commit 2a985c94ee920c1d0baec5d0c02204788c130b33)

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2021-04-13 18:33:24.000000000', 'files': ['tools/normalize_acl.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/4286aa0276b8918a3379d05c20e2aaaabe73eab5', 'message': "Allow delete permissions in Gerrit ACLs

We now have the option to assign delete permissions to groups in
Gerrit, which would grant them the ability to delete branches
through the WebUI or API. Since this is a new setting, it was not

commit_message:
Allow delete permissions in Gerrit ACLs

We now have the option to assign delete permissions to groups in
Gerrit, which would grant them the ability to delete branches
through the WebUI or API. Since this is a new setting, it was not
previously recognized by our linter. Extend it so that we won't
raise an error if this appears in an ACL.

Change-Id: I2b182d31e3ca5809a53aec851015341f2e67825d

commit_message:
Ensure ansible_fqdn is set

The ipaclient ansible role requires that ansible_fqdn is defined but
due to [1] we don't have ansible_fqdn inside of ansible_facts.  This
uses the 'fqdn' ansible fact for ansible_fqdn which is equivalent.

[1]: https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/4e79336d69e
6b7fa4b026922bac7953bafeee96d

Related-Bug: 1915761
Closes-Bug: 1923248
Change-Id: I0a740e86588c96fff24fa09698c35e492d1c64db

commit_message:
Fix dispatching issues with least connection ipv6 test

The IPv6+TCP+LC scenario test have randomly failed with an incorrect
dispatch. Adding a delay between requests seems to fix this behavior
(shamelessly inspired by the IPv4 LC scenario tests).

Change-Id: I68baab227f844a057f2abf77b295c3af287a333e

commit_message:
[Train-only] Fix the tripleo-container-stop role in train

When we backported the tripleo_container_stop tasks for some services,
we forgot that in train the role was called 'tripleo-container-stop'.

Without this change upgrade tasks fail with:
2021-04-09 17:46:45 | The error appears to be in '/home/stack/undercloud-ansible-xd1nbsp0/external_upgrade_steps_tasks.yaml': line 84, column 13, but may
2021-04-09 17:46:45 | be elsewhere in the file depending on the exact syntax problem.
2021-04-09 17:46:45 |
2021-04-09 17:46:45 | The offending line appears to be:
2021-04-09 17:46:45 |
2021-04-09 17:46:45 |   - import_role:
2021-04-09 17:46:45 |       name: tripleo_container_stop
2021-04-09 17:46:45 |             ^ here
2021-04-09 17:46:45 | Exception: Online Upgrade failed

Tested by applying this patch to a previously failing train UC upgrade,
which now succeeds.

Closes-Bug: #1923235

Change-Id: I089a0e7ca22e51ff7171a68d97ae296f5a2a4199

commit_message:
add availability-zone-affinity-anti-affinity-filter review.

Change-Id: Ifcbf3b8c372ec6577fbbbdd62f9abeb6e0dbad13
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/80/756380/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================ Availabilty Zone Affinity Filter ================================ https://blueprints.launc/+spec/availability-zone-affinity-anti-affinity-filter Instances can have different scheduling requirements such as low latency, higher reliability and availability. Consequently, such instances are required to be created within af single availability zone for low latency between instances or on different availability zones for higher reliability in a group of instances. Currently, it is not possible to create instances with such requirements unless each availability zone is specified for each instance creation. This spec introduces a new filter scheduler where a group of instances can be created by affinity policy on a single availability zone or instances can be created each on a different availability zone with anti-affinity policy. Problem description =================== Currently, it is not possible to create a group of instances with affinity and anti-affinity policies within availability zones. Instances with low latency requirements between them, must be created on nearby hosts such as hosts in an availability zone. Currently, a group of instances can only be created in an availability zone if it is specified manually at time of creation. It is not practical since any later migrations or instance creations can violate it. Currently server group affinity filter only works on a single host not an availability zone. Instances with higher reliability and availability should be created on different racks or locations such as hosts from different availability zones. Now, instances can only be created by hosts from different availability zones, if it is specified as a flag in creation. It is not practical to keep track of available zones, and instances in the group. Current server group anti-affinity filter only guarantee instances in the server group with anti-affinity policy on different hosts, but these hosts can be in the same availability zone. Use Cases --------- Consider two availability zones, AZ1 and AZ2. AZ1 includes three hosts and AZ2 includes two hosts. .. code:: +---------------------------+ +------------------+ | AZ1 | | AZ2 | +-+-----+--+-----+--+-----+-+ +-+-----+--+-----+-+ |host1| |host2| |host3| |host4| |host5| +-----+ +-----+ +-----+ +-----+ +-----+ There are two use cases in creating instances with respect to availability zones. Affinity, to create instances in a single availability zone. Anti-affinity, to create instances in different availability zones. In affinity use case, a group of instances is required to be created within a single availability zone. A user creates an instance within the group and affinity policy, later instances will be created on hosts in the same availability zone. For example, if the first instance is created on host1 in AZ1, later instances will be created on host1, host2, or host3. In anti-affinity use case, a group of instance should be created on different availability zones. Meaning that not any two instances reside on a host in the same availability zone. A user creates an instance in the group with anti-affinity policy, Later instances will be created on hosts from different availability zones. For example, if the first instance is created on host4 in AZ2, the second instance, will be created on host1, host2, or host3 in AZ1. Proposed change =============== A new filter scheduler will be added where the logic of filtering hosts in availability zones based on policy (affinity or anti-affinity) is implemented. Also server groups are used to record instances and policies. We go over the components in the following, as well as an alternative approach. Server Group ------------ In order to record the instances in the group and their policies we need a structure. Server groups can be used, but as server groups are used in host affinity filter, we need to distinguish between these two types of server groups. In order to use server groups for availability zone affinity, we use a scheduler hint. A hint ``availability_zone_affinity``, is used to distinguish a server group on hosts and a server group in availability zones. The default value is false (``availability_zone_affinity=False``), if the user does not specify the scheduler hint, it is assumed as false and the server group is considered as a host server group. This guarantees current functionality is unchanged, any server groups before this change is considered as host server group. When the scheduler hint is used (``availability_zone_affinity=True``), the server group is considered as an availability zone server group. Using the current server group structure with an schedule hint, benefit the backward compatibility and fewer changes in the code. .. code:: +-------------------------------+ | Server Group Policy | +-------------------------------+ | Affinity | | Anti-affinity | +-------------------------------+ Availability Zone Affinity Filter --------------------------------- The scheduler filter will filter the hosts if the ``availability_zone_affinity=True``, otherwise it will not be applied. Like other filters, it takes the same approach to filter the candidate hosts. In case of affinity, it checks the availability zone of an instance in the server group, if the availability zone of the host and the instance matches it will return true, otherwise returns false. In case of anti-affinity, it creates a set of the availability zones of the instances in the server group. The filter takes the availability zone of the host and if it is not in the set returns true, otherwise returns false. Server Group Affinity Filter ---------------------------- Affinity filter should be updated to check for the scheduler hint, if ``availability_zone_affinity=False`` or it is not specified, the filter should be applied to the host otherwise should return. Alternatives ------------ Instead of using a scheduler hint to distinguish between host server groups and availability sever groups, we can modify server groups to have other policies for the availability zone, such as ``az-affinity`` and ``az-anti-affinity``. This approach needs more changes in the code, but in this approach the server group affinity filter will be unchanged. .. code:: +--------------------------------------------+ | Server Group Policy | +--------------------------------------------+ | affinity -------------------------> host | | anti-affinity --------------------> host | | az-affinity ---------> availability zone | | az-anti-affinity ----> availability zone | +--------------------------------------------+ availability zone affinity filter checks for the type of affinity and if it does not match the ``az-affinity`` and ``az-anti-affinity`` it returns. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Added impact of one more filter for each host in instance creation scheduling. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Upgrade impact -------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- * navid pustchi Feature Liaison --------------- npustchi Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Functional tests and unittests. Documentation Impact ==================== Documents should be updated with examples on how to use this scheduler filter. References ========== History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Victoria - Introduced

commit_message:
Enable REST quiescing

This blueprint proposes on demand instance quiescing using REST APIs.

Change-Id: Ib9ad99527bb1de2aef52e236032b68a62de0d401
Blueprint: on-demand-vm-quiescence
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/10/702810/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: On Demand VM Quiescence ======================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/on-demand-vm-quiescence This spec aims to allow the quiescing of VMs on demand by actors other than nova itself. Problem description =================== While Nova currently supports quiescing and unquiescing of VMs for drivers that support it (libvirt with enabled QGA), this functionality is only ever invoked when Nova itself is asked to create a snapshot of a running instance. No other actor, such as an external backup tool, is able to quiesce a VM. Use Cases --------- When creating a snapshot of a Cinder volume attached to a nova vm through Cinder, the filesystem of that server isn't frozen beforehand. This means that the newly created snapshot is potentially out of date at the time of creation. Allowing Cinder to tell Nova to quiesce the server would fix this issue. Proposed change =============== The goal of this proposal is to expose the ability to quiesce individual instances on demand to non-nova actors. To this end, this functionality will be exposed in the REST API using the existing ``os-server-external-events`` endpoint with two new named events for quiescing and unquiescing instances. The Nova API will then process the request as usual, resending it to the appropriate compute node via RPC which will then attempt to quiesce (or unquiesce) the given VM. Access to these new operations will be controlled through a new policy rule: ``compute:quiesce``. To track if an instance is quiesced or unquiesced [#fsfreezestatus]_, a new Task State, ``Quiescing``, will be introduced into the Nova state machine. This state will be set once the instance has been successfully quiesced and cleared on a successful unquiescing. Any quiescing and unquiescing operation will have an action log entry. Once the two operations have been separated as described, an instance could end up stuck in a state of prolonged or even endless quiescence in cases where an actor fails to unquiesce an instance or the unquiescing operation fails. To remedy this, a configurable value for the maximum duration of quiescence will be introduced. A periodic clean up task will then unquiesce any instances that exceed this duration, identifying them by analysing action log entries for instances with the ``Quiescing`` task state. .. [#fsfreezestatus] This could potentially be done for LibVirt Vms using the ``guest-fsfreeze-status`` command of the Quemu Guest Agent, but LibVirts python binding does not expose this functionality. Alternatives ------------ * A potential third REST API operation could also be introduced to query the state of instance quiescence. * Rather then using the ``os-server-external-events`` endpoint with different operations to access the quiescence functionality, separate endpoints could be introduced instead. This has been proposed in the past, but failed to make it through the review process [#previousattempt]_. * For a more detailed monitoring of the quiescing process, a more complex set of states could be added to the Nova VM: +-------------+-------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | Name | Type | Description | +=============+=======+=============================================================================+ | QUIESCED | VM | Marks a quiesced instance | +-------------+-------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | Quiescing | Task | Signifies that an instance is transitioning from ``ACTIVE`` to ``QUIESCED`` | +-------------+-------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | Unquiescing | Task | Signifies that an instance is transitioning from ``QUIESCED`` to ``ACTIVE`` | +-------------+-------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+ * Alternatively, addition of Task and/or Virtual Machine states could be avoided by adding a ``quiesced`` field to the Instance model. Similarly, the automated cleanup process could be simplified by recording the time of quiescence directly in the Instance Model removing the need to analyze action log entries to identify instances that have remained quiesced for too long. .. [#previousattempt] `<https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/mitaka/approved/expose-quiesce-unquiesce-api.html>`_ Data model impact ----------------- Per the above proposal, a new value of Task State will be added: ``Quiescing``. Additional changes would be needed if one of the alternatives is chosen. REST API impact --------------- There are two new proposed event requests for the ``os-server-external-events`` endpoint: .. code-block:: json { "events": [ { "name": "quiesce"/"unquiesce", "server_uuid": "3df201cf-2451-44f2-8d25-a4ca826fc1f3", } ] } Field definitions: name The name of the event: * quiesce * unquiesce server_uuid: Server UUID of the instance which si to be quiesced. The proposed responses to these two events: .. code-block:: json { "events": [ { "code": 200, "name": "unquiesce", "server_uuid": "3df201cf-2451-44f2-8d25-a4ca826fc1f3", "status": "completed" } ] } name Name of the event: * quiesce * unquiesce status Event status. Possible values: * "completed" if accepted by Nova * "failed" if a failure is encountered code Event result code. Possible values: * 200: Accepted * 404: Server could not be found server_uuid Same value as provided in original request. Possible HTTP response codes: * The HTTP response code 200 is returned on success. * The HTTP response code 207 is returned if any event fails with 422 code. * The HTTP response code 400 is returned on a bad request. * The HTTP response code 401 is returned if request is unauthorized. (keystone) * The HTTP response code 403 is returned if request is forbidden. (policy) * The HTTP response code 404 is returned if no server could be found. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Nova client should be extended to utilize the new API operations and thus expose the functionality to cloud users. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- #. A new policy rule will be created: ``compute:quiesce`` to control access to the new external events. The default value will be set to "rule:admin_or_owner" to match existing snapshot rules. #. A new configuration value named ``max_quiesce_time`` in nova.conf in the [DEFAULT] section. This will define the maximum amount of time an instance may remain quiesced for the automated cleanup process. Developer impact ---------------- None Upgrade impact -------------- None, unless one of the above described alternatives is chosen. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mareklycka Other contributors: None Feature Liaison --------------- Feature liaison: Liaison Needed Work Items ---------- #. Expose the Quiesce REST API #. Modify the State machine as described above #. Implement a periodic cleanup routine Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tempest testing of new REST API endpoints needs to be introduced as well as tests for the above described automated clean up routine. Documentation Impact ==================== * New policy and configuration options for operators. * New REST API functionality for developers and end users.

commit_message:
Fix NovaVncProxyNetwork removal

In commit [1], NovaVncProxyNetwork was removed.  Unfortunately, the
patch to backport [2] was incorrectly merged and some references to
NovaVncProxyNetwork were not removed and renamed to NoveLibvirtNetwork.

This patch fixes those references.

commit_message:
Fix NovaVncProxyNetwork removal

In commit [1], NovaVncProxyNetwork was removed.  Unfortunately, the
patch to backport [2] was incorrectly merged and some references to
NovaVncProxyNetwork were not removed and renamed to NoveLibvirtNetwork.

This patch fixes those references.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/778617
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/781077
